channel.title: Defense
channel.description: News, Analysis and Opinion from POLITICO

item.title: Hegseth revives push to punish Sen. Mark Kelly
item.description: The Defense secretary appealed a ruling this month in favor of the former Navy captain.

media:content.media:title: Sens. Ruben Gallego (D-Ariz.) and Mark Kelly (D-Ariz) depart a press conference before the State of the Union address at the U.S. Capitol in Washington, on Feb. 24, 2026.

item.dc:creator: By Leo Shane III, Connor O'Brien and Kyle Cheney
item.dc:contributor: By Leo Shane III, Connor O'Brien and Kyle Cheney

item.title: Trump’s Iran buildup risks drowning out affordability message
item.description: The massive accumulation of aircraft carriers and fighter jets in the Middle East, coupled with the Pentagon’s Venezuela operation, could cost billions of dollars.

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by Bill Kuchman/POLITICO (source images via Getty Images and Tajh Payne/US Navy via Getty Images)
media:content.media:title: Main.McLearyGould.IranBuildup green.jpg

item.dc:creator: By Paul McLeary and Joe Gould
item.dc:contributor: By Paul McLeary and Joe Gould

item.title: Newsom says Trump’s attacks are bringing Europe together
item.description: It’s the president’s one contribution to the continent, the California governor said.

media:content.media:title: California Gov. Gavin Newsom prepares to address the audience at the Munich Security Conference in Munich, Germany, on Feb. 13, 2026.

item.dc:creator: By Gregory Svirnovskiy
item.dc:contributor: By Gregory Svirnovskiy

item.title: US ambassador to NATO: America is 'not leaving' Europe
item.description: His comments are part of a more conciliatory tone American officials are taking during the Munich Security Conference.

media:content.media:description: US NATO Ambassador Whitaker: The US is 'not abandoning Europe'
media:content.media:title: US NATO Ambassador Whitaker: The US is 'not abandoning Europe'

item.dc:creator: By Paul McLeary
item.dc:contributor: By Paul McLeary

item.title: Top Republican lawmakers spar over Greenland
item.description: Without naming him directly, Sen. Thom Tillis appeared to fire back at Sen. Lindsey Graham over his comments on Greenland's sovereignty.

media:content.media:title: Sen. Thom Tillis (R-N.C.) speaks to reporters before a weekly Republican policy luncheon at the U.S. Capitol on June 3, 2025, in Washington.

item.dc:creator: By Paul McLeary
item.dc:contributor: By Paul McLeary

item.title: Munich Day 2: Marco Rubio’s test
item.description: U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio is unlikely to flame the Munich Security Conference like Vice President JD Vance did last year — but don’t expect him to arrive bearing apologies for President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: By Joe Gould
item.dc:contributor: By Joe Gould

item.title: Zelenskyy pushes US to intensify pressure on Russia
item.description: The Ukrainian leader hinted that Congress might need to step in on security guarantees.

media:content.media:description: President Zelenskyy: 'Only United States can stop Putin'
media:content.media:title: President Zelenskyy: 'Only United States can stop Putin'

item.dc:creator: By Jack Detsch and Felicia Schwartz
item.dc:contributor: By Jack Detsch and Felicia Schwartz

item.title: Kelly expects Trump to come after him again
item.description: The Arizona Democrat and five other lawmakers with military or intelligence backgrounds have been attacked by the president over a video they released in November reminding military personnel not to follow illegal directives.

media:content.media:description: "This is about the free speech rights of over 2 million retired veterans. ... He's going after them," Sen. Mark Kelly said of the president.
media:content.media:title: Sen. Mark Kelly (D-Ariz.): Trump administration has 'doubled down on stupid'

item.dc:creator: By Connor O'Brien
item.dc:contributor: By Connor O'Brien

item.title: Lindsey Graham to allies: Get over Greenland
item.description: The South Carolina Republican offered a fairly optimistic take on a NATO alliance that's been battered by the dispute over Greenland.

media:content.media:description: Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) says 'Greenland is behind us'
media:content.media:title: Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) says 'Greenland is behind us'

item.dc:creator: By Joe Gould
item.dc:contributor: By Joe Gould

item.title: Europe looks for US resolve as Ukraine talks bog down
item.description: The Trump administration’s attempt to end the war hasn’t produced major breakthroughs as the war approaches its fourth anniversary.

media:content.media:title: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy speaks during a press conference with President Donald Trump following their meeting at Trump’s Mar-a-Lago club on Dec. 28, 2025, in Palm Beach, Florida.

item.dc:creator: By Felicia Schwartz, Paul McLeary and Jack Detsch
item.dc:contributor: By Felicia Schwartz, Paul McLeary and Jack Detsch

item.title: House leaders say lawmakers can't attend Munich Security Conference as official delegation
item.description: Some members were still planning to participate in the event.

media:content.media:title: Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) departs after speaking with reporters outside the Capitol on Jan. 9, 2026.

item.dc:creator: By Joe Gould, Jack Detsch and Connor O'Brien
item.dc:contributor: By Joe Gould, Jack Detsch and Connor O'Brien

item.title: Federal court blocks Hegseth effort to punish Democratic senator
item.description: The judge said the Pentagon had “trampled” on Sen. Mark Kelly’s First Amendment freedoms.

media:content.media:title: Sen. Mark Kelly takes an elevator in the Capitol after speaking out against Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth’s efforts to censure on Jan. 12.

item.dc:creator: By Connor O'Brien and Josh Gerstein
item.dc:contributor: By Connor O'Brien and Josh Gerstein

item.title: Poll: Top NATO allies don’t think US helps deter enemies anymore
item.description: The United States' eroding reputation is raising fresh questions about the stability of the global order that has held for decades, and of the country's strength on the world stage.

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by Anna Wiederkehr/POLITICO (source images via Getty)
media:content.media:title: TPP: NATO Allies and the US

item.dc:creator: By Nicholas Vinocur and Erin Doherty
item.dc:contributor: By Nicholas Vinocur and Erin Doherty

item.title: US signals limited military pullback from Europe
item.description: “We will continue to show up,” America's ambassador to NATO said.

media:content.media:title: The 32 flags of the NATO member states are seen at the NATO headquarters building on April 4, 2025, in Brussels, Belgium.

item.dc:creator: By Paul McLeary, Victor Jack and Jack Detsch
item.dc:contributor: By Paul McLeary, Victor Jack and Jack Detsch

item.title: The transatlantic alliance is down but not out
item.description: The Munich Security Conference will serve as a gut check of the frayed relationship, and whether Europe can hold on to its emerging self-assurance.

media:content.media:title: Vice President JD Vance (right) and British Foreign Secretary David Lammy shake hands during a bilateral meeting on the sidelines of the Munich Security Conference in Munich, Germany on Feb. 14, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By Paul McLeary, Laura Kayali and Felicia Schwartz
item.dc:contributor: By Paul McLeary, Laura Kayali and Felicia Schwartz

item.title: Trump says he won’t extend nuclear arms treaty with Russia
item.description: The New START deal was the last vestige of arms control between the world’s largest superpowers.

media:content.media:credit: Russian Defense Ministry Press Service via AP
media:content.media:title: This photo taken from a video distributed on Dec. 9, 2020, by the Russian Defense Ministry Press Service, shows a rocket launch as part of a ground-based intercontinental ballistic missile test at the Plesetsk facility in northwestern Russia.

item.dc:creator: By Jack Detsch
item.dc:contributor: By Jack Detsch

item.title: CIA ends publication of World Factbook reference tool
item.description: The site appeared online in 1997.

media:content.media:title: CIA Director John Ratcliffe arrives for a classified briefing with senators at the Capitol on Jan. 7, 2026.

item.dc:creator: By Associated Press
item.dc:contributor: By Associated Press

item.title: Trump prepares to let go of arms control with Russia
item.description: Russian and U.S. nuclear arsenals could expand for the first time in three decades.

media:content.media:title: Russian ballistic missiles being prepared for a parade.

item.dc:creator: By Jack Detsch and Paul McLeary
item.dc:contributor: By Jack Detsch and Paul McLeary

item.title: Trump’s Golden Dome, a year in, is struggling to take shape
item.description: The president vowed to build a missile defense shield for the country in three years. It’s nowhere close to being done.

media:content.media:title: President Donald Trump and Rep. Jim Banks (R-Ind.) listen as Space Force Gen. Michael Guetlein speaks in the Oval Office about the Golden Dome missile defense system May 20, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By Audrey Decker
item.dc:contributor: By Audrey Decker

item.title: Cables show Trump’s moves on Greenland rattled other nations
item.description: State Department cables obtained by POLITICO lay bare the frustrations — and aspirations — of US allies and adversaries watching Trump seek the Danish island.

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by Bill Kuchman/POLITICO (source images via Getty Images and AP)
media:content.media:title: Main.Toosi.Greenland.jpg

item.dc:creator: By Nahal Toosi, Paul McLeary and Victor Jack
item.dc:contributor: By Nahal Toosi, Paul McLeary and Victor Jack

item.title: Poll: Trump voters support military intervention in more countries
item.description: 65 percent of Trump voters say the U.S. should take military action in at least one country, according to a new POLITICO poll.

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by Anna Wiederkehr/POLITICO (source images via AP and Getty)
media:content.media:title: TPP-Venezuela-Foreign-Intervention

item.dc:creator: By Giselle Ruhiyyih Ewing and Leo Shane III
item.dc:contributor: By Giselle Ruhiyyih Ewing and Leo Shane III

item.title: US officials: More Ukraine, Russia talks coming next week
item.description: This week’s meetings were the first time all three countries sat face-to-face for talks to try and hash out a ceasefire.

media:content.media:title: President Donald Trump and Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskyy shake hands at the start of a joint news conference at Trump's Mar-a-Lago club, Dec. 28, 2025, in Palm Beach, Florida.

item.dc:creator: By Paul McLeary and Felicia Schwartz
item.dc:contributor: By Paul McLeary and Felicia Schwartz

item.title: Pentagon no longer views China threat as top priority
item.description: The National Defense Strategy, a dramatic shift from previous administrations, reinforces many of the military moves already undertaken by the president.

media:content.media:title: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth arrives to brief senators at the U.S. Capitol, Jan. 7, 2026.

item.dc:creator: By Jack Detsch
item.dc:contributor: By Jack Detsch

item.title: ‘Old wine in a new bottle’: Greenland negotiations resemble an earlier deal
item.description: A 1951 treaty between the U.S. and Denmark already covers much of what a potential agreement on the island would include.

media:content.media:title: Vice President JD Vance gestures as he tours Pituffik Space Base on March 28, 2025, in Greenland.

item.dc:creator: By Paul McLeary and Jack Detsch
item.dc:contributor: By Paul McLeary and Jack Detsch

item.title: Republicans narrowly fend off bid to limit Trump on Venezuela
item.description: GOP lawmakers pulled out all the stops to manage a tie vote and keep a war powers effort at bay a week after Senate Republicans quashed a similar measure.

media:content.media:title: Reps. Jim McGovern (D-Mass.), left, and Thomas Massie (R-Ky.) authorized the bipartisan war powers resolution to require President Donald Trump to seek congressional approval for renewed military action against Venezuela.

item.dc:creator: By Connor O'Brien
item.dc:contributor: By Connor O'Brien

item.title: Trump stands down on Greenland — and Republicans exhale
item.description: GOP lawmakers insisted U.S. military force against the Arctic island was never actually an option.

media:content.media:title: President Donald Trump meets with NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte during a meeting on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, Jan. 21, 2026.

item.dc:creator: By Joe Gould, Connor O'Brien and Leo Shane III
item.dc:contributor: By Joe Gould, Connor O'Brien and Leo Shane III

item.title: Trump orders active duty troops to prepare for Minnesota deployment
item.description: The move signals a potentially more harder-line approach by the White House.

media:content.media:title: People gather near the post office during a protest, Sunday, Jan. 18, 2026, in Minneapolis.

item.dc:creator: By Paul McLeary
item.dc:contributor: By Paul McLeary

item.title: DHS turns on border chief over $2M office renovation plan
item.description: As DHS looks to increase deportations and build the wall, commissioner Rodney Scott requested a pricey office renovation project.

media:content.media:title: U.S. Customs and Border Protection commissioner Rodney Scott is being blamed for slow progress on construction of a wall along the border with Mexico.

item.dc:creator: By Daniel Lippman
item.dc:contributor: By Daniel Lippman

item.title: Confronted with thorny problems, Trump turns to the military
item.description: The president has used the armed forces during his second term as an initial option rather than a last resort.

media:content.media:title: President Donald Trump addresses a crowd of service members during a celebration open in honor of the Army's 250th anniversary on June 10, 2025, in Fort Bragg, North Carolina.

item.dc:creator: By Jack Detsch and Paul McLeary
item.dc:contributor: By Jack Detsch and Paul McLeary

item.title: The World Cup’s most dreaded gatecrasher isn’t a fan but a drone
item.description: Officials from 11 American host cities met with military and law-enforcement leaders to game out security threats to the summertime tournament.

media:content.media:title: MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, New Jersey, will be the site of the World Cup final match in July. Local law-enforcement officials from the New York-New Jersey region were recently trained by FBI officials in the use of counter-drone technology as part of security preparations.

item.dc:creator: By Sophia Cai
item.dc:contributor: By Sophia Cai
